rdf:Alt.rdf:li: {\rtf1 }
{\rtf1 hi welcome to video 2 of the punctuation}
{\rtf1 section we're going to cover commas}
{\rtf1 today so what we'll do is we'll start}
{\rtf1 with 6 main common uses then we'll look}
{\rtf1 at three common comma errors and then}
{\rtf1 we'll do a little practice exercise and}
{\rtf1 then we'll come back and look at}
{\rtf1 restrictive and non-restrictive clauses}
{\rtf1 so the six main comma uses the first is}
{\rtf1 to separate lists or elements in a}
{\rtf1 series so here's an example he went to}
{\rtf1 class comma dinner comma and then hope}
{\rtf1 you'll notice there's a comma between}
{\rtf1 the last and the second to last item in}
{\rtf1 the list that's also known as the serial}
{\rtf1 comma or the Oxford comma there is much}
{\rtf1 debate around the serial comma extra}
{\rtf1 comma but for the purposes of this class}
{\rtf1 because it's a technical editing class}
{\rtf1 we're going to always use the serial}
{\rtf1 comma or the Oxford comma and that's}
{\rtf1 because the serial comma Oxford comma}
{\rtf1 reduces ambiguity and if we're editing}
{\rtf1 technical information we want to reduce}
{\rtf1 as much ambiguity as possible the second}
{\rtf1 main use is to connect two independent}
{\rtf1 clauses so you've got two clauses that}
{\rtf1 can stand alone as sentences if you've}
{\rtf1 got those two you have to connect them}
{\rtf1 with the coordinating conjunction so we}
{\rtf1 talked about this in video 1 you can go}
{\rtf1 back and look at the list of}
{\rtf1 coordinating conjunctions but here's an}
{\rtf1 example}
{\rtf1 he went to class comma but he fell}
{\rtf1 asleep so we've got two independent}
{\rtf1 clauses connected by a comma thirdly to}
{\rtf1 set off introductory elements you can}
{\rtf1 could include it individual words these}
{\rtf1 could include phrases or these could}
{\rtf1 include clauses so he's an example of a}
{\rtf1 subordinate clause because he was tired}
{\rtf1 comma he fell asleep in class so that}
{\rtf1 because he was tired as an introductory}
{\rtf1 clause that's introducing the reason why}
{\rtf1 this student fell asleep in class}
{\rtf1 our fourth main common use is to offset}
{\rtf1 non-essential information we'll come}
{\rtf1 back to restrictive versus non}
{\rtf1 restrictive clauses we'll look at those}
{\rtf1 in more detail in a second here but}
{\rtf1 here's an example John went to the lake}
{\rtf1 comma which was shallow from the}
{\rtf1 you're out right so which was shallow}
{\rtf1 from the drought is non-essential}
{\rtf1 information the main point of the}
{\rtf1 sentence here is that John went to the}
{\rtf1 lake the which was shallow from the jel}
{\rtf1 the drought is extra information}
{\rtf1 information about the lake that's not}
{\rtf1 essential to the meaning of the sentence}
{\rtf1 and we'll talk more about this and in a}
{\rtf1 little bit number five we use commas to}
{\rtf1 separate coordinate adjectives so}
{\rtf1 coordinate adjectives are adjectives}
{\rtf1 that describe the same noun so these are}
{\rtf1 like lists of adjectives describing a}
{\rtf1 noun and so the rule of thumb is if we}
{\rtf1 can wreak an reverse the adjectives or}
{\rtf1 we can put in the word and in between}
{\rtf1 the adjectives then they should probably}
{\rtf1 take a comma so it's easiest to look at}
{\rtf1 an example so John has a long comma}
{\rtf1 arduous commute we can reverse those two}
{\rtf1 so John has a arduous arduous comma long}
{\rtf1 commute that would be fine we can also}
{\rtf1 add the word and in between the two}
{\rtf1 John has a long and arduous can you okay}
{\rtf1 so if we can pass those tests we want to}
{\rtf1 we know that we want to put a comma in}
{\rtf1 between the adjectives the second}
{\rtf1 example the Bears are a tough football}
{\rtf1 team so you've got to two adjectives}
{\rtf1 tough and football right both describing}
{\rtf1 team but you can't reverse those so the}
{\rtf1 Bears are a football tough team so it}
{\rtf1 fails that test and we can't say the}
{\rtf1 Bears are a tough and football team and}
{\rtf1 so in which case these are non}
{\rtf1 coordinate adjectives they don't}
{\rtf1 coordinate with each other and so we}
{\rtf1 don't put a comma in between the two and}
{\rtf1 then finally we use commas to separate}
{\rtf1 geographical items so cities and states}
{\rtf1 Chicago Illinois for example okay so now}
{\rtf1 let's talk about three common comma}
{\rtf1 errors and there's obviously more than}
{\rtf1 just three but uses the most common the}
{\rtf1 first is using a comma to separate a}
{\rtf1 noun and a verb or a noun phrase and a}
{\rtf1 verb phrase so an example of that is the}
{\rtf1 most important aspect of}
{\rtf1 , is completing the reading so we've got}
{\rtf1 this noun phrase aspect of class and}
{\rtf1 we've got this verb phrase is completing}
{\rtf1 and we're using a comma to separate}
{\rtf1 those two incorrectly so that's an}
{\rtf1 incorrect example secondly using a comma}
{\rtf1 between two verbs in a compound}
{\rtf1 predicate and we talked about what a}
{\rtf1 compound predicate was in the grammar}
{\rtf1 video lesson but a compound predicate}
{\rtf1 just as a matter of recap is when you've}
{\rtf1 got two verb phrases in your predicate}
{\rtf1 describing the same subject and so John}
{\rtf1 turned the corner and ran into the light}
{\rtf1 pole we've got two verb phrases one}
{\rtf1 turned the corner into and ran into the}
{\rtf1 light pole those two are two verb}
{\rtf1 phrases describing what John did and so}
{\rtf1 we've incorrectly inserted a comma}
{\rtf1 between the two verb phrases now this}
{\rtf1 would be punctuated correctly if we}
{\rtf1 added a subject to the second half of}
{\rtf1 this sentence because we added a subject}
{\rtf1 the second half of the sentence then we}
{\rtf1 would have two independent clauses and}
{\rtf1 we know that if we've got two}
{\rtf1 independent clauses we can use a comma}
{\rtf1 to join them up with a coordinating}
{\rtf1 conjunction thirdly using a comma}
{\rtf1 between nouns so the music teacher from}
{\rtf1 your high school comma and the football}
{\rtf1 coach are married and so we've got two}
{\rtf1 two noun phrases music teacher and}
{\rtf1 football coach and we incorrectly}
{\rtf1 inserted a comma between those two noun}
{\rtf1 phrases and so you may have noticed}
{\rtf1 there's a couple things that that cause}
{\rtf1 comma errors one people tend to insert}
{\rtf1 commas where there's natural pauses as}
{\rtf1 you're reading something aloud in your}
{\rtf1 own head or aloud or actually aloud so}
{\rtf1 for example in our first example we said}
{\rtf1 the most important aspect of class is}
{\rtf1 completing the readings so if we if we}
{\rtf1 naturally have this break sometimes we}
{\rtf1 feel inclined to insert a comma between}
{\rtf1 that noun in that verb when that's not}
{\rtf1 appropriate so that's the first thing is}
{\rtf1 as your as}
{\rtf1 to look for as an editor is these}
{\rtf1 natural breaks that may be punctuated}
{\rtf1 incorrectly the second thing to look for}
{\rtf1 is coordinating conjunctions and so if}
{\rtf1 you if you see a coordinating}
{\rtf1 conjunction you're editing antennae}
{\rtf1 should raise and so you'll notice in}
{\rtf1 these examples we've got the}
{\rtf1 coordinating conjunction and people tend}
{\rtf1 to insert commas where there's a}
{\rtf1 coordinating conjunction even if it's}
{\rtf1 not appropriate to and so just as a}
{\rtf1 reminder we only want to use the comma}
{\rtf1 and the coordinating conjunction if}
{\rtf1 we've got two independent clauses on}
{\rtf1 either side of the comma okay so now}
{\rtf1 that we got six common uses for commas}
{\rtf1 and three common errors let's take a}
{\rtf1 quick second and do a practice exercise}
{\rtf1 so click anywhere on the screen to}
{\rtf1 launch the exercise okay}
{\rtf1 restrictive versus non restrictive}
{\rtf1 clauses these are often that verses}
{\rtf1 which clauses and so a restrictive}
{\rtf1 clause or restrictive phrase restrict}
{\rtf1 the meaning of a sentence just as if}
{\rtf1 defined in the name and these never have}
{\rtf1 commas and so let's take a look at an}
{\rtf1 example the driver's test that John took}
{\rtf1 was different than the test that Jane}
{\rtf1 took so we've actually got two}
{\rtf1 restrictive clauses here that John took}
{\rtf1 and we also that Jane took is also a}
{\rtf1 restrictive gralton clause and those}
{\rtf1 clauses restrict the meaning of the test}
{\rtf1 as it's a clause that refers to a}
{\rtf1 specific test right so if we removed}
{\rtf1 those phrases it would fundamentally}
{\rtf1 change the nature or meaning of the}
{\rtf1 sentence so if we remove them we just}
{\rtf1 say the driver's test was different than}
{\rtf1 the test but that changes the meaning of}
{\rtf1 the sentence so though that's essential}
{\rtf1 information that John took in that Jane}
{\rtf1 took versus a non restrictive clause or}
{\rtf1 a non restrictive phrase which provides}
{\rtf1 information that is nice to have but}
{\rtf1 doesn't fundamentally change the meaning}
{\rtf1 of the sentence so these are offset or}
{\rtf1 surrounded by commas so here's an}
{\rtf1 example the car comma which is red comma}
{\rtf1 is out of my price range}
{\rtf1 so which is red is nice to have but it's}
{\rtf1 not essential if we remove it the}
{\rtf1 sentence remains intact the sentence}
{\rtf1 remains the meaning of the sentence does}
{\rtf1 not change so we could say the car is}
{\rtf1 out of my price range and that's the}
{\rtf1 circle sort of the whole point of the}
{\rtf1 sentence which is ratted to additional}
{\rtf1 information so we've got the thumb rule}
{\rtf1 and you kind I kind of alluded to the}
{\rtf1 thumb rule already so if you stick your}
{\rtf1 thumb over a phrase that you're}
{\rtf1 wondering about so sort of as an editor}
{\rtf1 pro tip if you see a phrase that starts}
{\rtf1 with that or which that should raise}
{\rtf1 your editing antennae and you may need}
{\rtf1 to decide whether or not it's punctuated}
{\rtf1 correctly so stick your thumb over the}
{\rtf1 phrase you're wondering about that is}
{\rtf1 just remove it and if it's fundamentally}
{\rtf1 different it's probably a restrictive}
{\rtf1 clause right so it's probably a that}
{\rtf1 needs to have the word theft and it}
{\rtf1 probably needs to not have any commas if}
{\rtf1 the sentence is pretty much the same but}
{\rtf1 it's just missing some descriptive}
{\rtf1 information it's probably non}
{\rtf1 restrictive in which case you should use}
{\rtf1 the phrase begin the phrase with which}
{\rtf1 and en offset it with commas so here's}
{\rtf1 an example of the thumb rule the Crazy}
{\rtf1 Horse monument blanked we're trying to}
{\rtf1 decide that or which was dedicated in}
{\rtf1 1984 attracts visitors from all over the}
{\rtf1 world so if we remove our visa thumb}
{\rtf1 rule and remove the phrase in question}
{\rtf1 we would say the Crazy Horse monument}
{\rtf1 attracts visitors from all over the}
{\rtf1 world the fact that it was dedicated in}
{\rtf1 1984 is kind of non-essential}
{\rtf1 information it's just extra information}
{\rtf1 so we would start that phrase with which}
{\rtf1 and surround it with commas so that's it}
{\rtf1 there will be one more practice exercise}
{\rtf1 looking at restrictive clauses versus}
{\rtf1 non restrictive clauses go ahead and}
{\rtf1 click anywhere on the screen to launch}
{\rtf1 that practice exercise and we'll see you}
{\rtf1 next time}
